blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: “Killing Eve”, Episodes 5 & 6
title: “Killing Eve”, Episodes 5 & 6
body:
It seems to me that Eve’s husband was deliberately made to be such a flat character. In their opening argument in episode six, he even rejects his embodiment of the “boring, dick, husband type”, but goes on to lecture her concerning both her professional passion and her obsession with capturing Villanelle. The way he describes Villanelle frames her as a typical psycho/murderer lady, but his argument as a whole targets Eve as the predatory role with an uncontrollable drive to catch Villanelle. While he doesn’t seem to understand the complexities of the case, this scene shows that he also doesn’t quite understand his wife. It only adds to the contrast of her as a strong, dynamic, boss b*tch who is oddly paired with a meek, passive man. To make things worse, I love how he attempts to erase his claims and push their rather serious fight under the rug. The fight is one of the first times viewers are hearing his perspective, and we get to see that he is jealous of Eve’s intrigue and attention towards Villanelle. Eve is consistently bored by the ordinary and intrigued by the exceptional- it almost makes sense for her to be with a personality more similar to Villanelle’s. The elimination of her already platonic relationship with her husband as a love interest would make this dynamic more interesting. In these episodes we also learn of Villanelle’s pattern of castrating male victims. She jealously says that Anna only loved her husband for his penis. This is significant because Villanelle is assumedly jealous of Eve’s husband, while Eve’s husband is also jealous of Villanelle.

-Katie

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: “Killing Eve,” Ep. 5 and 6
title: “Killing Eve,” Ep. 5 and 6
body:
In episode 5, Eve receives her suitcase back from the forensics team. This is her first chance to really look at the items that Villanelle gifted her. The scene is clearly meant to suggest eroticism and desire between both Eve and Villanelle. The music most clearly reflects this, as it starts off slow and a bit eerie, but slowly builds louder as Eve puts on the whole outfit. The fervor with which Eve strips down to put on the clothing gifted to her shows the desire she has for her romanticized version of Villanelle. Additionally, Villanelle seems to reflect this desire, as all the clothing she has picked out for Eve looks as though it was custom made for her body. Eve realizes this too as shown by the camera panning over Eve’s butt and breasts as she runs her hands slowly over the dress. The way the camera pans over Eve’s body as she dresses gives the scene a voyeuristic feeling, as if the viewer shouldn’t be there, which contribute to the sense viewers get that Eve knows her desires are misplaced, but she cannot help it nonetheless. Overall, the scene strengthens the continuous theme of a fatal attraction between Eve and Villanelle because we know that the two women will never be together in any sort of normal relationship. The fact that it is the dress that is touching Eve, rather than Villanelle herself, reflects this idea that there will always have to be a distance between the two.

- giselle

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

summary: “Killing Eve,” Episodes 5 & 6
title: “Killing Eve,” Episodes 5 & 6
body:
In our last class, we heavily discussed the extent to which Killing Eve’s characters follow the “psycho-lesbian” trope. At the time, I argued that I didn’t think that these characters’ queerness was explicitly attached to their psychopathic tendencies, but watching these last two episodes has altered my perception a bit.

Firstly, with Villanelle, these episodes further entangle her sexuality with her assassin motives. We see this when we learn of her pattern of castrating male victims as well as her jealousy towards Anna’s husband because she says Anna only loved him for his penis. We also see Eve piecing together that Villanelle may have castrated her first victim because he assaulted her. This also brings in another harmful trope we’ve discussed in class that assumes queer women’s sexuality stems from traumatic experiences with men.

Secondly, although Eve is undoubtedly the character with better morals, we do see a seemingly out-of-character explosion of violence when she punches her husband in the face and assaults him. She does this in response to Niko accusing her of “getting off on sniffing out a psycho”, relating back to our attempted characterization of Eve and Villanelle’s mutual obsession. I can’t tell if Eve’s assault is meant to be positioned and applauded as something a “strong woman” would do; regardless it left a bad taste in my mouth. 

Niko’s declaration is possibly the most explicit in attaching the two women in a sexual way, up until this point. However, the scene in which Villanelle chases Eve in her apartment and asks her to dinner can also be read through a queer lens as well, although it clearly isn’t a romantic gesture.

blog.title: At The Bottom Of The River
blog.description: Drowning in fandoms, slash and insecurity. Russian, 25.

summary: Finally watched Killing Eve. It was on my dashboard for a while, so I got curious. And I don’t regret a single second of it x)))...
body:
Finally watched Killing Eve. It was on my dashboard for a while, so I got curious.

And I don’t regret a single second of it x)))

- The CHARACTERS! And I not mean just the main ones, although Villanelle and Eve are amazing, but the others, too. They are so human, charismatic and relatable - Bill, Konstantin, Caroline, Kenny and of course my favorite (right after Villanelle) - Irina. I wish they didn’t kill Bill and Konstantin, though T__T

- The dynamic is great - honestly, it’s like pure fanfiction (and I mean it in a good sense), only on screen x) It’s the second fanfiction tv-show that I’ve watched (the first is Hannibal, ofc), and I’m all aboard with this. Gay power to the case-shows X)) I love it.

- The finale! Eve, dear, you took the definition of Gay Panic to the whole next level xD

- The humor. I love British shows so much x)

- V I L L A N E L L E. I absolutely adore her. There’s not nearly enough words to explain why she’s so precious and gorgeous, because it’s freaking everything she does and say. (And she reminds me of fem!Deadpool, but don’t mind me, I’m obsessed.)

- 10/10 would totally recommend bc DUH, it’s funny, it’s witty and it’s lesbian power so. Go watch it.

tags: just a shame that pbw's commitment to feminism doesn't extent to women that don't have the same body type as her 🙄
summary: I want to preface this by saying I really love Killing Eve. It's feminist narrative is so refreshing, and something that we...
body:
I want to preface this by saying I really love Killing Eve. It’s feminist narrative is so refreshing, and something that we don’t see enough of on screen.

Which is why the body shaming jokes it frequently makes are so grating. It makes sense with Villanelle’s character that she would be so harsh about people’s appearance - she’s a psychopath, after all. However, the show seems to support Villanelle’s put downs because all the fat characters seen on screen are lazy, given almost no lines and shown as physically unattractive to the point of repulsion.

Strikingly, all these characters are women. (Think of Inga, Konstantin’s off screen wife) The only member of the main cast that isn’t skinny is Konstantin himself (and possibly Bill, but he doesn’t last long), and he is still portrayed as attractive despite being of a different body type to Carolyn (his former love interest).

It’s such a shame the show is pointing fun at fat women when it strives so hard in other aspects to portray women as more three dimensional than the roles prescribed to them by the male gaze.

summary: 2018 in Review: The 10 Best Dramas
title: 2018 in Review: The 10 Best Dramas
excerpt: We’re nearly four weeks away from belting a chorus of “Auld Lang Syne,” and you know what that means: It’s time to kick off TVLine’s Year in Review, highlighting the b…
description:
1. KILLING EVE

The year’s top TV drama also happened to be the year’s happiest surprise. BBC America’s irresistible cat-and-mouse thriller put a wickedly clever spin on the standard crime drama, with writer Phoebe Waller-Bridge layering plenty of pitch-black laughs into her tale of a lowly intelligence analyst hunting down a glamorous assassin. The pulse-pounding pace made it a perfect binge-watch, and it boasted a pair of 2018’s most unforgettable performances: Jodie Comer, as seductive contract killer Villanelle, and Sandra Oh, as bored paper-pusher Eve, who doggedly tracked Villanelle across the globe… and discovered her inner badass along the way.

7. THE GOOD FIGHT

After spending its inaugural season working those pesky rookie kinks out, the Good Wife spinoff returned with a vastly improved sophomore run that lived up to the lofty standards set by its Emmy-winning predecessor. Series creators Robert and Michelle King took a big creative risk by letting art imitate our current, extremely incendiary political life, and it paid huge dividends. The series’ eerily prescient and stingingly satirical take on all things Trump was alternately entertaining and sobering. As a result, The Good Fight has emerged from The Good Wife‘s shadow, establishing itself as both a thoroughly addictive and wholly distinct series in its own right.

reblog.comment:
1. KILLING EVE

The year’s top TV drama also happened to be the year’s happiest surprise. BBC America’s irresistible cat-and-mouse thriller put a wickedly clever spin on the standard crime drama, with writer Phoebe Waller-Bridge layering plenty of pitch-black laughs into her tale of a lowly intelligence analyst hunting down a glamorous assassin. The pulse-pounding pace made it a perfect binge-watch, and it boasted a pair of 2018’s most unforgettable performances: Jodie Comer, as seductive contract killer Villanelle, and Sandra Oh, as bored paper-pusher Eve, who doggedly tracked Villanelle across the globe… and discovered her inner badass along the way.

The series’ eerily prescient and stingingly satirical take on all things Trump was alternately entertaining and sobering. As a result, The Good Fight has emerged from The Good Wife‘s shadow, establishing itself as both a thoroughly addictive and wholly distinct series in its own right.

summary: EW's Entertainers of the Year: Sandra Oh is amazing — just ask 'Schitt's Creek' actor Daniel Levy
body:
EW’s Entertainers of the Year: Sandra Oh is amazing — just ask ‘Schitt’s Creek’ actor Daniel Levy

“From the first scene of episode 1, Killing Eve is this magical alchemy of comedy and drama and suspense and fashion and music and art. It shouldn’t work so harmoniously, and yet it does.”

summary: I'm watching the pilot of Killing Eve with my mom and at the scene where Villanelle is going back to her apartment and turns...
body:
I’m watching the pilot of Killing Eve with my mom and at the scene where Villanelle is going back to her apartment and turns around to look at a woman, my mom said “I saw that girl before…” And I thought, yeah she did other shows and stuff, BUT AFTER TWO FUCKING MINUTES SHE YELLED “OH IT’S THE ONE THAT KNOCKED OVER THE LITTLE GIRL’S ICE CREAM!”.

I have now the confirmation that my mom is Lena Luthor, she doesn’t recognize someone if they’re wearing a wig.

reblog.comment:

summary: hey I’m not sure if i want to read the book cuz i don’t wanna spoil the shows mood, but i have a theory about the 12. the group...
question: hey I’m not sure if i want to read the book cuz i don’t wanna spoil the shows mood, but i have a theory about the 12. the group of 12 or G12 is a financial union of the 12 most economically powerful nations in the world. 🤔🤔 am i getting warm or cold?
answer:
i think it might be more complicated than that but ur probably on the right track. the first book at least doesn’t go too much into it.

and the book doesn’t really spoil the show’s mood bc they’re just so different?

summary: Regarding 1x05 and how in control Villanelle is of the situation when she sits and eats at Eve’s place, I’ve always found this...
caption:
Regarding 1x05 and how in control Villanelle is of the situation when she sits and eats at Eve’s place, I’ve always found this bit to be really fascinating because when Eve decides to still dwell on Bill’s death asking “Why Bill” you will hear Villanelle actually sigh and look down at Eve’s hand, lying on top of the prison file. It’s a minute thing but you can catch the critical and structural advantages of Villanelle’s power over the other woman. It’s like watching her reinvent something again and again but in different and more meaningful ways.

I feel that Villanelle knows that she can achieve a certain mutuality between herself and the woman she has set her eyes on because of the existent emotional checkbox - which is that she can “give” her presence to Eve (who we know is highly interested in Villanelle anyway). It’s like an immense demand for visibility, you know? The way Villanelle manages to create a stark contrast to the loss Eve experiences otherwise when she wraps her hand around Eve’s own and squeezes it. It’s interesting that this dredges up a reason for Eve to combat her own feelings too, imo. Because I mean, I don’t want to get into the layers of the “He was slowing you down” line but it’s such an active push-back that - for a moment - there is nothing but them, because even when Eve grabs the knife to try to hurt Villanelle at the end she also feels the connection.

And yea.

I don’t know where I’m going with this. I just really like that the The Touch acts as the lynchpin of their confrontation and that Villanelle is dead-set on it.
